[[File:Bertrand Russell leads anti-nuclear march in London, Feb 1961.jpg|300px|thumbnail|right|[[Bertrand Russell]] (centre, with hat), alongside his wife, Edith, and [[Ralph Schoenman]], with [[Michael Randle]] (second left), leading the Committee 100 march to the Ministry of Defence, London, on 18 February 1961]]
The '''Committee of 100''' was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[anti-war]] group. It was set up in 1960 with a hundred public signatories by [[Bertrand Russell]], [[Ralph Schoenman]]<ref name=ringsleben>[https://archive.is/20121223213037/http://www.archiveshub.ac.uk/news/maryringsleben.html Papers of Mary Ringsleben]</ref> and Reverend [[Michael Scott (Reverend)|Michael Scott]] and others. Its supporters used mass [[nonviolent]] resistance and [[civil disobedience]] to achieve their aims.
==History==
The idea of a mass civil disobedience campaign [[anti-nuclear|against nuclear weapons]] emerged early in 1960 in discussions between Ralph Schoenman (an activist in the [[Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament]] (CND)), and [[Hugh Brock]], [[April Carter]] (both of the [[Direct Action Committee]] against nuclear war), [[Ralph Miliband]], Alan Lovell and [[Stuart Hall (cultural theorist)|Stuart Hall]]. Schoenman approached Bertrand Russell, the president of CND, with the idea.<ref name=carroll>Carroll, S.J., [http://sro.sussex.ac.uk/6910/1/Carroll%2C_Samantha_Jane.pdf ''Fill the Jails: Identity, Structure and Method in the Committee of 100, 1960 – 1968''], University of Sussex, 2010.</ref> Russell resigned from the presidency of CND in order to form the Committee of 100, which was launched at a meeting in London on 22 October 1960 with a hundred signatures. Russell was elected as president<ref name=Driver/> and [[Michael Randle]] of the Direct Action Committee was appointed secretary.
Russell explained his reasons for setting up<ref>[http://www2.lse.ac.uk/library/archive/online_resources/cnd/cnd_1.aspx LSE.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111108135211/http://www2.lse.ac.uk/library/archive/online_resources/cnd/cnd_1.aspx |date=2011-11-08 }}</ref> the Committee of 100 in an article in the ''[[New Statesman]]'' in February 1961:
{{quote|The Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament has done and is doing valuable and very successful work to make known the facts, but the press is becoming used to its doings and beginning to doubt their news value. It has therefore seemed to some of us necessary to supplement its campaign by such actions as the press is sure to report. There is another, and perhaps more important reason for the practice of civil disobedience in this time of utmost peril. There is a very widespread feeling that however bad their policies may be, there is nothing that private people can do about it. This is a complete mistake. If all those who disapprove of government policy were to join massive demonstrations of civil disobedience they could render government folly impossible and compel the so-called statesmen to acquiesce in measures that would make human survival possible. Such a vast movement, inspired by outraged public opinion is possible, perhaps it is imminent. If you join it you will be doing something important to preserve your family, compatriots and the world.<ref>Russell, B., "Civil Disobedience", ''New Statesman'', 17 February 1961.</ref>}}
Many in the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, including some of its founders, supported the Committee of 100's campaign of civil disobedience and in its first year it received more in donations than CND had received in its first year.<ref name=Driver/> Several of the early CND's activists, including some members of its executive committee, had been supporters of the Direct Action Committee and in 1958 CND had cautiously accepted direct action as a possible method of campaigning;<ref name=Driver/> but, largely under the influence of [[Canon John Collins]], the CND chairman, the CND leadership opposed any sort of unlawful protest, and the Committee of 100 was created as a separate organisation partly for that reason and partly because of personal animosity between Collins and Russell. It has been suggested<ref name=Taylor/> that this separation weakened the campaign against nuclear weapons.
The Committee's campaign tactic was to organise sit-down demonstrations, which were not to be undertaken without at least 2,000 volunteers pledging to take part.<ref name=ringsleben/> Many eminent people participated in the sit-downs but few of the 100 signatories took part in the Committee's activities.<ref name=Taylor/> Demonstrators were required to adopt a discipline of non-violence. In a briefing document the Committee of 100 said, "We ask you not to shout slogans and to avoid provocation of any sort. The demonstrations must be carried out in a quiet, orderly way. Although we want massive support for these demonstrations, we ask you to come only if you are willing to accept this non-violent discipline."<ref name=leaflet>''Mass Resistance - Wethersfield - Ruislip'', Committee of 100, 1961.</ref> Demonstrators were recommended to remain limp if arrested and to refuse to co-operate in any way until inside the police station.
At first, the Committee of 100 differed from CND only in its methods, and they had the same objectives. Within the Committee, however, there were different ideas about civil disobedience, direct action and non-violence. Bertrand Russell saw mass civil disobedience merely as a way of getting publicity for the unilateralist cause. Those from the Direct Action Committee were absolute pacifists (some of them Christians)<ref name=shelley/> who followed [[Gandhi]], and they regarded direct action as a way of creating a non-violent society. Ralph Schoenman and others, including the [[anarchism|anarchists]] who later led the organisation,<ref name=shelley/> saw direct action as a sort of insurrection that could force the state to give up nuclear weapons. These factions argued among themselves about whether non-violence was a matter of principle or just a tactic<ref name=Taylor/> and whether the Committee should limit itself to demonstrations or adopt a more thoroughgoing anarchist programme.<ref name=shelley/> [[Nicolas Walter]], a prominent member of the Committee, said later that it had been an anarchist organisation from its inception and that the hundred signatories were, in effect, a front.<ref>Walter, Nicolas, ''Damned Fools in Utopia'', PM Press, 2011.</ref>
===1961===
The Committee's first act of civil disobedience on 18 February 1961 was a sit-down demonstration at the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] in Whitehall, London, to coincide with the expected arrival of {{USS|Proteus|AS-19|6}} on the [[River Clyde]].<ref name=Driver/> ([https://web.archive.org/web/20081012030105/http://www.topfoto.co.uk/gallery/CND/ppages/ppage66.html Picture]) Between 1,000 and 6,000 people took part.<ref name=Driver/><ref name=fromprotest>''From Protest to Resistance'', a ''Peace News'' pamphlet, Mushroom Books, Nottingham, 1981, p.18 {{ISBN|0-907123-02-3}}.</ref> Somewhat to the surprise of the Committee, there were no arrests.<ref name=Driver/> At the next sit-down demonstration, on 29 April in Parliament Square, the police arrested 826 people.<ref name=Driver/> There were also marches and sit-downs against nuclear testing and demonstrations at the [[Embassy of the United States in London|US]] and Soviet embassies in London and at the [[Polaris missile|Polaris]] [[submarine base]].<ref name=fromprotest/>
On 17 September, [[Battle of Britain]] Day, supporters blocked the pierheads at [[Holy Loch]] and the approaches to [[Trafalgar Square]]. ([https://web.archive.org/web/20110929195234/http://www.topfoto.co.uk/gallery/CND/ppages/ppage95.html Picture]) The September demonstration is regarded as the high-water mark of the Committee of 100.<ref name=Driver/><ref name=Taylor/> A week before the demonstration, the hundred committee members were summoned to court without charge under the Justices of the Peace Act of 1361<ref>http://www.legislation.gov.uk/aep/Edw3/34/1 Justices of the Peace Act, 1361.</ref> because they "incited members of the public to commit [[breach of the peace|breaches of the peace]]" and were likely to continue to do so. The court bound them to a promise of good behaviour for twelve months; thirty-two, including Bertrand Russell, then aged 89, refused and chose to go to prison instead. It is estimated that 12,000 to 15,000 attended the demonstration despite the invocation of the Public Order Act, which effectively made it illegal to be in the vicinity of central London that day. Several thousand sat down<ref name=Driver/><ref name=shelley/> and there were 1,314 arrests, but no violence from demonstrators despite allegations of police brutality.<ref name=Driver/>
The success of the September demonstration encouraged the Committee to move from symbolic sit-down demonstrations in London to mass direct action at the places where nuclear weapons would be deployed, and they planned simultaneous demonstrations on 9 December to walk on to air force bases at [[RAF Wethersfield|Wethersfield]], [[RAF Northolt|Ruislip]], [[RAF Brize Norton|Brize Norton]], [[RAF Cardiff|Cardiff]]<ref name=fromprotest/> to sit on the runways and to prevent planes from taking off, and street sit-downs in [[Bristol]], [[Manchester]] and [[York]].<ref name=leaflet/><ref name=shelley>Shelley, Diana, "Influx or exodus? Anarchists and the Committee of 100", ''Anarchy'', No. 50, April 1965.</ref> By this time the authorities had begun to take the Committee of 100 more seriously. The official response had escalated from prosecution for incitement to breach of the peace to prosecution for the much more serious offences of conspiracy and incitement to breach the Official Secrets Act. Six organisers, the "Wethersfield Six", were charged with these offences and five later imprisoned for eighteen months: [[Ian Dixon]], [[Terry Chandler]], [[Trevor Hatton]], Michael Randle, [[Pat Pottle]]; and the sixth, [[Helen Allegranza]], to twelve months.<ref name=Driver>Driver, Christopher, ''The Disarmers: A Study in Protest'', London: Hodder and Stoughton, 1964.</ref><ref name=Taylor>Taylor, R., ''Against the Bomb'', Oxford University Press, 1988.</ref> ([https://web.archive.org/web/20080706031129/http://www.topfoto.co.uk/gallery/CND/ppages/ppage52.html Picture]) Bertrand Russell said that he was equally responsible, but the authorities ignored him and concentrated on the six young, unknown Committee of 100 officers.<ref name=fused>[http://digitalcollections.mcmaster.ca/case-study/fused-fizzing-and-ready-go-bertrand-russell-takes-streets ''Fused, Fizzing and Ready to Go Off''.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706185301/http://digitalcollections.mcmaster.ca/case-study/fused-fizzing-and-ready-go-bertrand-russell-takes-streets |date=2011-07-06 }}</ref><ref name=chandler>[https://archive.is/20130420072301/http://www.britishcaselaw.co.uk/chandler-terence-norman-v-dpp-no-1-1962-ukhl-2-12-july-1962 Chandler (Terence Norman) v DPP (No 1).]</ref> 3,000 military and civilian police were mobilised at Wethersfield. 5,000 demonstrated there and 850 were arrested.<ref name=Driver/> The Wethersfield demonstration was regarded by many as a failure<ref name=Driver/><ref name=shelley/><ref name=peers/> and it was the Committee's last act of large-scale civil disobedience. There were recriminations within the Committee,<ref name=Driver/> one internal memorandum saying that its policies had turned it into "a public spectacle, a group isolated from the general body of public opinion and feeling."<ref name=Driver/> [[Herbert Read]] resigned from the Committee, saying that the action was "strategically foolish".<ref name=shelley/> The Committee was weakened by the imprisonment of its officers.
The force used by the police at sit-down demonstrations surprised many of the demonstrators, which, with the Committee's insistence on nonviolence and the use of pre-emptive arrests for conspiracy, discouraged many, and support dwindled.<ref>Myers, F.E., "Civil Disobedience and Organizational Change: The British Committee of 100", ''Political Science Quarterly,'' Vol. 86, No. 1. (March 1971), pp. 92-112.</ref> The Committee's plan to "fill the jails" by means of mass civil disobedience, and thus compel the government to respond to their demands, was frustrated by the authorities imprisoning a few important members and ignoring the rest.<ref name=carroll/> The harsh sentences on the Wethersfield Six "brought home to the Committee its inadequacy when faced with the might of the State,"<ref name=Taylor/> and some of the Committee's leaders were not willing to "fill the jails", mounting strenuous appeals against conviction<ref name=chandler/> or, in the case of Pat Pottle, going on the run.<ref name=shelley/><ref name=fromprotest/>
===1962–1968===
By 1962, half of the original 100 signatories had resigned and had been replaced.<ref name=Taylor/> The Committee was in debt<ref name=Driver/> and had to face the failure of its mass civil-disobedience campaign.<ref name=peers/> It was dissolved and the campaign was decentralized,<ref name=ringsleben/> thirteen regional committees, each with a hundred members, becoming responsible for organizing demonstrations, with a co-ordinating National Committee. Of the regional committees, the London Committee of 100 was the most active and influential. A national magazine was launched by the London Committee in April 1963, published under the name ''Resistance'' from January 1964. Like CND, the Committee of 100 had begun with a self-appointed and unelected leadership, and, like CND, it faced pressure for greater participation by supporters. This re-organisation was intended to involve more people in decision making and to spread demonstrations throughout the country<ref name=carroll/> and had been anticipated in the creation of a number of subgroups in December 1961.<ref name=Taylor/> Although Bertrand Russell opposed it,<ref name=Taylor/> he wrote that "The Committee has found that its support, named and on file, is so extensive that regional committees are required to accommodate this strength,"<ref>Russell, B. ''Yours Faithfully, Bertrand Russell'', Open Court, Chicago and La Salle, 2001, p. 282.</ref> But supporters became exhausted by the number of demonstrations they attended<ref name=carroll/><ref name=shelley/> and "neither London nor the regional committees had their full complement of a hundred."<ref name=shelley/>
In March 1962 Russell addressed a sit-down demonstration in Parliament Square against the sentences on the Wethersfield Six. All the 1,172 protesters were arrested, but there was a growing feeling that such demonstrations were becoming an end in themselves<ref>London Committee of 100, ''Beyond Counting Arses'', 1963. Cited in Gopodway, David ''[[Anarchist Seeds Beneath the Snow]]'', Liverpool University Press, 2006.</ref> and would not now create a mass movement against nuclear weapons.<ref name=Taylor/> (Contemporary research showed that public support for the unilateralist cause actually declined in the period when the Committee of 100 was most active.<ref>Snyder, W.P., ''The Politics of British Defense Policy, 1945-1962,'' Ohio University Press, 1964, p. 61.</ref>) A sit-down of 7,000 outside the Air Ministry planned for the following September had to be called off because of lack of support,<ref name=fused/><ref name=peers>Peers, Dave, [http://www.marxists.org/history/etol/newspape/isj/1963/no012/peers.htm "The impasse of CND"], ''International Socialism'', ''International Socialism'', No. 12, Spring 1963, pp. 6–11.</ref> a "public assembly" being held instead.<ref name=fromprotest/>
To underline its opposition to Russian nuclear weapons as well as those of the West, the Committee held a demonstration in [[Red Square]], [[Moscow]], at an international congress of the [[World Peace Council]] in the summer of 1962 calling for the abolition of all nuclear weapons and attacking the Soviet system.<ref name=driver>Christopher Driver, ''The Disarmers'', London: Hodder and Stoughton, 1964.</ref><ref>[http://www.whatnextjournal.co.uk/Pages/Sectariana/SFReply.html Review: Solidarity Forever.]</ref><ref>''The Guardian'', 12 July 1962.</ref>
From 1962 onwards, the Committee became increasingly radical and extended its campaigns to issues other than nuclear weapons. [[Peter Cadogan]], an officer of the Committee, said it was "trying to go in 12 directions at once", including campaigning for civil liberties in [[Greece]], against [[Harold Wilson]]'s failure to produce a promised [[Vietnam War|Vietnam peace initiative]] and against siting [[London Stansted Airport|London's third airport]] at Stansted.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1571755/Peter-Cadogan.html Obituary of Peter Cadogan.]</ref> Diana Shelley, a member of the London Committee of 100, said that as the Committee adopted objectives other than nuclear disarmament it became "less non-violent".<ref name=shelley/> In 1963 Russell resigned, though he remained in sympathy with the early aims and activities of the Committee and was careful not to denigrate it publicly.<ref name=Taylor/> Following his departure, the public image of the Committee deteriorated, many signatories also resigned and "the Committee of 100 ventured even further into the wilderness of libertarian politics".<ref name=Taylor/>
Members of the Committee were responsible for the [[Spies for Peace]]<ref>Camley, N., ''Cold War Secret Bunkers'', Pen & Sword Books, 2007.</ref> revelations in 1963 about the [[Regional Seat of Government|Regional Seats of Government]], a network of secret government bunkers, and later for the escape of [[George Blake]]<ref>Pottle, P., and Randle M., ''The Blake Escape'', Sphere Books, 1990.</ref> from [[Wormwood Scrubs (HM Prison)|Wormwood Scrubs Prison]].
The Committee's interest in Greek politics was sparked by the banning of a march by the Greek "Bertrand Russell Committee of 100" in Easter 1963, by the expulsion of some of the British Committee of 100's members when they attempted to join the march, and by the murder of [[Grigoris Lambrakis]], a Greek MP and peace activist.<ref name=Driver/> Plans to protest against the London visit by [[Paul of Greece|King Paul]] and [[Frederika of Hanover|Queen Frederika]] in July 1963 were met by official attempts to prevent the demonstrations<ref name=ewing/> and draconian prison sentences on demonstrators. The government was criticized in the press for the severity of its treatment of the demonstrators and eventually there were embarrassing climb-downs. Some of the sentences were overturned on appeal and the Home Secretary, [[Henry Brooke, Baron Brooke of Cumnor|Henry Brooke]], had to offer financial compensation. One of the demonstrators, [[Donald Rooum]], proved that an offensive weapon had been planted on him and forced a public inquiry that criticized the police and led to the eventual imprisonment of three officers.<ref name=Driver/> But a nine-months sentence on Terry Chandler, secretary of the London Committee, was upheld on appeal.<ref name=ewing>Ewing, K. D., [https://books.google.com/books?id=Yba3aFKQg64C&pg=PA172&dq=The+Contrasting+Fortunes+of+Terry+Chandler&hl=en&ei=9S0LTrz6HcSzhAeSmOX7Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=The%20Contrasting%20Fortunes%20of%20Terry%20Chandler&f=false "Cold war, civil liberties and the House of Lords"], in Campbell, Tom, K.D. Ewing and Adam Tomkins (eds), ''The Legal Protection of Human Rights'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2011.</ref> Diana Shelley said that the imprisonment of Chandler, "the force which had driven" the Committee throughout the summer,<ref name=shelley/> had a profoundly damaging effect. Four years after these events, following the [[Greek military junta of 1967-1974|1967 military coup]] in Greece, a "non-violent invasion" of the Greek embassy resulted in prison sentences of up to fifteen months for Committee of 100 demonstrators.<ref name=Taylor/>
The Committee of 100 was wound up in October 1968.
==Name== According to Christopher Driver, the name was suggested by [[Gustav Metzger]] and Ralph Schoenman, who derived it from the [[Guelphs and Ghibellines|Guelph]] Council of 100.<ref name=Driver/>
==Legacy== Before the Committee of 100 came on the scene, civil disobedience on this scale was virtually unknown in Britain, although the researches of its advocates uncovered it as a strand of protest throughout the centuries.<ref>Cadogan, Peter, "Non-violence as a reading of history", ''Anarchy'', No. 20, October 1962, London, Freedom Press.</ref> The Committee of 100, and comparable movements outside the UK (not least the [[Civil Rights Movement]] in the United States), made it a common method of social action, now familiar in environmental, animal rights and peace protests. However, the Committee's strict insistence on nonviolence is rare. The Committee also popularized a new method of organization derived from anarchism and hitherto unfamiliar to those in traditional political parties: without formal membership and based on decentralization and autonomous, self-selected "working groups" rather than elected executive committees.<ref name=shelley/><ref name=peers/>

page.title: Comptroller and Auditor General of Ireland

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Comptroller and Auditor General for Northern Ireland}} The '''Comptroller and Auditor General''' ('''C&AG''') ({{lang-ga|An tArd-Reachtaire Cuntas agus Ciste}}) is the constitutional officer responsible for public audit in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. The Office of the Comptroller and Auditor General is the public audit body for the Republic of Ireland and is headed by the C&AG.
The Comptroller and Auditor General is ex-officio member of the [[Standards in Public Office Commission]] and of the [[Referendum Commission]].
The C&AG is a member of the [[International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions]].
The current Comptroller and Auditor-General is [[Seamus McCarthy]] (since 28 May 2012).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?fn=/documents/aboutus/Biography_EN.htm |title=Biography of Comptroller and Auditor General|publisher=Office of the Comptroller and Auditor General |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
==Constitutional officer and independence== The office of Comptroller and Auditor General was established under Article 33 of the [[Constitution of Ireland]]. The C&AG is appointed by the [[President of Ireland|President]] on the nomination of [[Dáil Éireann]]. The office has its origins in Article 62 of the [[Constitution of the Irish Free State]] of 1922 as implemented by the '''Comptroller and Auditor-General Act 1923''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1923/en/act/pub/0001/index.html |title=Comptroller and Auditor-General Act 1923 |publisher=Office of the Attorney General |date=1923 |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> which provided that the Comptroller and Auditor-General ({{lang-ga|Árd-Scrúdóir}}) (as the office was then known) was to be appointed by [[Dáil Éireann]]. The 1923 Act and the '''Comptroller and Auditor General (Amendment) Act 1993'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1993/en/act/pub/0008/index.html |title=Comptroller and Auditor General (Amendment) Act 1993 |publisher=Office of the Attorney General |date=1993 |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> are the two principal legislative instruments governing the C&AG. Both the Constitutional and legislative provisions ensure the absolute independence of the C&AG and the Office of the C&AG to operate independently of government. The C&AG makes reports to [[Dáil Éireann]] on the accounts of bodies falling within its remit, essentially the State or State bodies and certain specified agencies or bodies receiving State funds. The reports are examined in detail by the [[Public Accounts Committee (Ireland)|Dáil Committee of Public Accounts]] ({{lang-ga|An Coiste um Chuntais Phoiblí}}).<ref>For the terms of reference of the Committee of Public Accounts see Appendix 1 to {{cite web|url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/parliament/media/committees/pac/reports2014/2014-Composite-report.pdf |title=Composite Report of the Public Accounts Committee 2014 | date=October 2014 |publisher=Houses of the Oireachtas |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
==Function== The Comptroller and Auditor General audits and reports on the use of public funds. It establishes that they are legal and used appropriately. It also examines the internal audit systems of public bodies and applies tests for value for money and effectiveness.
The bodies to be audited by the Comptroller and Auditor General are laid down by law. The Comptroller and Auditor General may receive new audit mandates from time to time regarding specific State bodies. It may lose its functions when bodies are dissolved, merged or rationalised.
The C&AG may not audit all recipients of State funding but only where audits of the recipient bodies are permitted or required by law. As a result, some bodies which receive a large amount of State funding or even are reliant on it, may not be subject to audit by the C&AG. This also has consequences for the remit of the Dáil [[Public Accounts Committee (Ireland)|Dáil Committee of Public Accounts]].
===Annual Reports on the Accounts of the Public Service=== The C&AG makes an Annual Report under the heading "Accounts of the Public Services" on funding granted by the [[Oireachtas]]. This includes the accounts of 41 Government Departments and offices, including the establishment of the [[President of Ireland]], as well as bodies such as the [[Garda Síochána]], prisons service, and the secret service. It publishes the relevant annual Appropriation Accounts together with the Annual Reports.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/documents/annualreports/2013/report/en/Report2013.pdf |title=Report on the Accounts of the Public Services 2013 | date=2014 |publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
===Health Sector=== The C&AG is responsible for auditing institutions in the health sector such as the Health Service Executive (HSE) and all Regional Health Boards. It also audits specified hospitals, and a variety of health-related State agencies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=1579&CatID=34&StartDate=1+January+2015|title=Health Sector |publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> It does not audit privately owned hospitals even though they may be in receipt of, or even reliant on, public funds.
If the C&AG considers problematic issues arise in relation to a Regional Health Board which merit a public accountability, it may issue what is known as a Section 6 Report, authorised by Section 6 of the Comptroller and Auditor General (Amendment) Act 1993.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=-1&CatID=24&UserLang=EN&m=6|title=Section 6 Reports|publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
===Educational Sector=== In the education sector, the C&AG audits all Irish Universities, Institutes of Technology and other specified third-level educational institutions such as the [[National College of Art and Design]]. It audits all Vocational Educational Committees. It also audits specified State bodies related to education such as the Higher Education Authority and the [[Royal Irish Academy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=-1&CatID=34&UserLang=EN&m=34 |title=Audited Bodies|publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
If the C&AG considers problematic issues arise in relation to a Vocational Education Committee which merit a public accountability, it may issue what is known as a Section 7 Report, authorized by Section 7 of the Comptroller and Auditor General (Amendment) Act 1993,.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=-1&CatID=25&UserLang=EN&m=6 |title=Section 7 reports|publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
===Financial Sector=== The Comptroller and Auditor General audits 25 State bodies in the financial sector including the [[National Treasury Management Agency]] ([[NTMA]]) and the [[National Asset Management Agency]] (NAMA).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=1584&CatID=34&StartDate=1+January+2015 |title=Financial Sector|publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
===Other Audited Bodies=== The Comptroller and Auditor General audits a very wide variety (115 in 2012) of State bodies or agencies as diverse as the [[National Library of Ireland]], the [[Road Safety Authority]] and the [[Abbey Theatre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=1585&CatID=34&StartDate=1+January+2015 |title=Accounts Audited|publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
It audits all 35 County Enterprise Boards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=1587&CatID=34&StartDate=1+January+2015 |title=Country Enterprise Boards|publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
===North/South Bodies=== The Comptroller and Auditor General carries out audits of the annual accounts of designated North/South public bodies with cross-border functions or activities relating to both the [[Republic of Ireland]] and [[Northern Ireland]]. These reports are prepared jointly with the [[Comptroller and Auditor General for Northern Ireland]].
Where it is considered that an issue of public accountability arises, a report is drawn up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/documents/specialreports/north_south/Accountability_of_North_South_Bodies_1999-2007.pdf |title=Accountability of North South Bodies 1999-2007|publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General|date=2 July 2008 |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
An interesting example of cross-border cooperation between the two Comptrollers and Auditors General is seen in the Bytel cross-border broadband project where the Northern Ireland Audit Office and the Office of the Comptroller and Auditor General of Ireland made a coordinated examination of the Bytel project. Although the two Comptrollers and Auditors General issued separate reports, they were issued simultaneously on 3 March 2015 and the report of each Comptroller and Auditor General was annexed to the report of the other. This coordinated examination was the first time this approach has been used.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=2074&CatID=17&StartDate=1+January+2015 |title=Press Release by the Comptroller and Auditor General of Ireland |publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General|date=3 March 2015 |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.niauditoffice.gov.uk/index/publications/recent_reports/bytel_media_release_25_feb_15.pdf |title=Press Release by the Northern Ireland Audit Office |publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General of Northern Ireland|date=3 March 2015 |location=Belfast |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
===Value for Money Reports=== The Office publishes special reports on Value for Money according to orthodox value for money criteria (efficiency, economy, effectiveness evaluation systems, procedures, practices) used by public audit bodies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=-1&CatID=5&UserLang=EN&m=13 |title=Value for Money Reports|publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
===Special Reports=== The C&AG from time to time publishes Special Reports on specific or general issues arising from audits, inspections or examinations carried out by him or his Office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audgen.gov.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=-1&CatID=4&UserLang=EN&m=13 |title=Special Reports|publisher=Comptroller and Auditor General |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
==Bodies not audited== The C&AG does not audit commercial semi-State bodies even when these are overwhelmingly owned by the State. Examples include the ESB (Electricity Supply Board)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esb.ie/main/about-esb/ESB_Annual_Report_and_Accounts_2013.pdf?v=3 |title=ESB Annual Report 2013 | date=2013 |publisher=ESB |location=Dublin |accessdate=4 March 2015}}</ref> or [[Bord na Móna]] (the Peat Board) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bordnamona.ie/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Annual-Report-2014-English.pdf|title=Bord na Móna Annual Report 2014 | date=2014 |publisher=Bord na Móna |location=Dublin |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> both of which are 95% owned by the State. Likewise it does not audit the accounts of [[Irish Water]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2013/en/act/pub/0006/print.html#part1 |title=Water Services Act 2013 |publisher=Office of the Attorney General |date=20 March 2013 |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
==List of Comptroller and Auditor Generals since 1923== *1923 – George McGrath *1944 – John Maher *1949 – William Eugene Wann *1953 – Liam Ó Cadhla *1964 – Eugene Suttle *1973 – Sean Mac Gearailt *1981 – P.L. McDonnell *1994 – John Purcell *2008 – John Buckley *2012 – [[Seamus McCarthy]]

{{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of Singapore.svg|150 px]]}}
'''Corruption in [[Singapore]]''' is generally perceived as low. Cases are mostly handled by the Singapore [[Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau]] (CPIB), a government agency in Singapore that investigates and prosecutes corruption in the public and private sectors.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chong|first1=Elena|title=Ex-police officer charged with warning dance clubs on raids|url=http://mypaper.sg/top-stories/ex-police-officer-charged-warning-dance-clubs-raids-20151204|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151206061833/http://mypaper.sg/top-stories/ex-police-officer-charged-warning-dance-clubs-raids-20151204|dead-url=yes|archive-date=6 December 2015|accessdate=4 December 2015|publisher=my paper}}</ref>
==Overview== Transparency International's 2017 Corruption Perception Index ranks the country 6th place out of 180 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.transparency.org/news/feature/corruption_perceptions_index_2017|title=Corruption Perception Index 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.transparency.org/cpi2015/|title=2015 Corruption Perceptions Index: Results|publisher=Transparency International|accessdate=1 February 2016}}</ref> The highest corruption risk area are identified by Government Defence Anti-Corruption Index as Operations followed by Finance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Singapore|url=http://government.defenceindex.org/countries/singapore/|website=Government Defence Anti-Corruption Index|publisher=Transparency International|accessdate=4 December 2015}}</ref>
Business executives surveyed in the [[World Economic Forum]]'s 2014–2015 [[Global Competitiveness Report]] reported no problems doing business in Singapore.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Competitiveness Report 2013-2014|url=http://reports.weforum.org/global-competitiveness-report-2014-2015/economies/#indexId=GCI&economy=SGP|publisher=The World Economic Forum|accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref>
The political reasoning behind why Singaporean corruption is perceived as being low is due to the fact that compared to neighboring nations such as Thailand or Indonesia, there is a theory that the powers of the state were able to pressure private interests into funneling capital into sectors that would ultimately benefit the public in the long term.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Doner|first=Richard F.|last2=Ritchie|first2=Bryan K.|last3=Slater|first3=Dan|date=April 2005|title=Systemic Vulnerability and the Origins of Developmental States: Northeast and Southeast Asia in Comparative Perspective|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/international-organization/article/systemic-vulnerability-and-the-origins-of-developmental-states-northeast-and-southeast-asia-in-comparative-perspective/EBFBFEDDFEFC2384B2273DD95F186302|journal=International Organization|language=en|volume=59|issue=2|pages=327–361|doi=10.1017/S0020818305050113|issn=1531-5088}}</ref>
==Indicators of corruption==
{| class="wikitable" |+ style="text-align: left;" | Common measurement of Corruption on Singapore <ref>Transparency International, [https://www.transparency.org/country/#SGP "Corruption in Singapore"]</ref> |- | scope="col" rowspan="2" | Year | scope="col" colspan="2" style="text-align: center; width: 200px;" | Corruption Perception Index <ref>Corruption Perceptions Index ranks countries/territories based on how corrupt a country’s public sector is perceived to be. It is a composite index, drawing on corruption-related data from expert and business surveys carried out by a variety of independent and reputable institutions.Scores range from 0 (highly corrupt) to 100 (very clean). Prior to 2012, the scope is up to scale of 10. Source: Transparency International</ref> | scope="col" colspan="2" style="text-align: center; width: 200px;" | Bribes Payer Index <ref>Bribe Payers Index ranks the world’s wealthiest and most economically influential countries according to the likelihood of their firms to bribe abroad. Scores range from 0 to 10, indicating the likelihood of firms headquartered in these countries to bribe when operating abroad. The higher the score for the country, the lower the likelihood of companies from this country to engage in bribery when doing business abroad. Source: Transparency International</ref> | scope="col" colspan="2" style="text-align: center; width: 200px;" | Control of Corruption <ref>Control of corruption reflects perceptions of the extent to which public power is exercised for private gain. This includes both petty and grand forms of corruption, as well as "capture" of the state by elites and private interests. It is one of the six dimensions of the Worldwide Governance Indicators.Point estimates range from about -2.5 to 2.5. Higher values correspond to better governance outcomes. Source: World Bank</ref> |- style="text-align: center; width: 100px;" | Rank || Score || Rank || Score|| Rank || Score |- style="text-align: center; width: 100px;" | 2017 || 6/168 || 84/100 || - || - || - || - |- style="text-align: center; width: 100px;" | 2016 || 7/168 || 84/100 || - || - || - || - |- style="text-align: center; width: 100px;" | 2015 || 8/168 || 85/100 || - || - || - || - |- style="text-align: center; width: 100px;" | 2014 || 7/175 || 84/100 || - || - || - || - |- style="text-align: center; width: 100px;" | 2013 || 5/177 || 86/100 || - || - || - || - |- style="text-align: center; width: 100px;" | 2012 || 5/176 || 87/100 || - || - || - || - |- style="text-align: center; width: 100px;" | 2011 || 5/183 || 9.2/10 || 8/28 || 8.3/10 || - || - |- style="text-align: center; width: 100px;" | 2010 || 1/178 || 9.3/10 || -|| -|| 99% || 2.18370827 |}
==Cases of corruption== ===SLA (2011)=== Former [[Singapore Land Authority]] (SLA) deputy director of technology and infrastructure, Koh Seah Wee, and former SLA manager, Christopher Lim Chai Meng, were sentenced to jail by the High Court on cheating and money laundering charges. Koh was sentenced to 22 years of jail after admitting to 59 charges and Lim was sentenced to 15 years imprisonment after admitting to 49 charges. Of the $12.2 million laundered, $7.5 million was recovered from Koh. Koh and Lim cheated SLA by using false invoices issued by ex-swim coach Ho Yen Teck who set up seven sole proprietorships to provide fake IT maintenance services and goods that were not delivered. Ho was jailed for 10 years for the conspiracy.<ref>https://sg.news.yahoo.com/two-former-sla-employees-plead-guilty-to-laundering--12-2-million.html</ref>
===SCDF and CNB (2012)=== In January 2012, two senior civil servants were arrested under graft charges. Former head of the [[Singapore Civil Defence Force]] (SCDF), Peter Lim Sin Pang,<ref>{{cite news|title=Gallery: Corruption trial of ex-SCDF chief Peter Lim underway|url=http://www.todayonline.com/photos/gallery-corruption-trial-ex-scdf-chief-peter-lim-underway|accessdate=13 January 2015|publisher=MediaCorp Press Ltd}}</ref> was arrested on 19 December 2011, while [[Central Narcotics Bureau]] (CNB) chief, Ng Boon Gay, was taken in for questioning on 4 January 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/The-Big-Story/The-Big-Story-3/Story/STIStory_759501.html | title=CPIB: Top men were arrested, being probed for graft | author=Leonard Lim | publisher=Straits Times| date=26 January 2012}}</ref> Both men were arrested in connection with the Prevention of Corruption Act relating to an IT contract,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest%2BNews/Singapore/Story/A1Story20120128-324386.html| title=Woman in centre of CPIB probe leads double life | publisher=AsiaOne| date=28 January 2012}}</ref> and in late January 2012, it was announced that both men are also facing disciplinary action by the Public Service Commission, which oversees the conduct of civil servants. After being interdicted, a step only taken when an individual “faces serious offences for which 'criminal proceedings or proceedings for his dismissal or reduction in rank are being contemplated'”,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/The-Big-Story/The-Big-Story-3/Story/STIStory_760299.html | title=CPIB probe: Duo facing civil service disciplinary proceedings as well | author=Toh Yong Chuan | publisher=Straits Times| date=28 January 2012}}</ref> the case provoked comment from Prime Minister [[Lee Hsien Loong]] who promised to punish both men if they are guilty of misconduct.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/The-Big-Story/The-Big-Story-3/Story/STIStory_759999.html | title=Govt will follow through on CPIB probe into 2 top men: PM Lee| author=Chua Lee Hoong| publisher=Straits Times| date=28 January 2012}}</ref>
The CPIB’s silence on this investigation came under the scrutiny of a number of MPs during a parliamentary sitting in February 2012. Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs, [[Teo Chee Hean]] then defended the CPIB, stating that any announcement on the outcome of the probe would have been premature and may have compromised the investigation. He also assured concerned MPs that all the findings of the investigation would be publicly reported once they had been finalised.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.asiaone.com/News/Latest%2BNews/Singapore/Story/A1Story20120214-327884.html | title= Premature announcement would have compromised CPIB investigations: DPM Teo | author= AsiaOne | publisher= AsiaOne | date=14 February 2012}}</ref>
Peter Lim Sin Pang was eventually dismissed from service formally in August 2013<ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-SCDF chief Peter Lim dismissed from service|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/ex-scdf-chief-peter-lim-dismissed-service|accessdate=13 January 2015|publisher=MediaCorp Press Ltd}}</ref> and found guilty while Ng Boon Gay retired<ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-CNB chief Ng Boon Gay retired from public service: MHA|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/ex-cnb-chief-ng-boon-gay-retired-public-service-mha|accessdate=13 January 2015|publisher=MediaCorp Press Ltd}}</ref> after being acquitted.
===NParks (2012)=== In July 2012, [[National Parks Board]]'s (NParks) purchase of 26 [[Brompton Bicycle|Brompton bikes]] costing $2,200 each sparked a nationwide uproar after it was revealed by a whistleblower on online forum [[HardwareZone]] of possible corruption due numerous red flags in the way the procurement was done.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asiaone.com/print/News/Latest%252BNews/Singapore/Story/A1Story20120802-362835.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-08-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029045642/http://www.asiaone.com/print/News/Latest%2BNews/Singapore/Story/A1Story20120802-362835.html |archivedate=2017-10-29 |df= }}</ref> Khaw, who initially defended NPark's purchase of the high-end foldable bikes, was criticised for handling the saga poorly.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mothership.sg/2013/10/hardwarezone-forum-broke-brompton-bike-fiasco/|title=How Hardwarezone Forum broke the Brompton bike fiasco|website=Mothership.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-18}}</ref> Subsequent investigation by the [[Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau]] resulted in National Parks Board assistant director Bernard Lim Yong Soon being fined $5,000 for lying to auditors about his relationship with the bicycle firm which was awarded the tender.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/brompton-bikes-case-nparks-officer-fined-maximum-5000-for-lying-to-auditors|title=Brompton bikes case: NParks officer fined maximum $5,000 for lying to auditors|last=migration|date=2014-06-10|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2017-11-18|language=en}}</ref>
===CPIB (2013)=== On 23 July 2013, Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) assistant director Edwin Yeo Seow Hionh was charged with misappropriating at least $1.7 million from the anti-graft agency between 2008 and 2012.<ref>http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/cpib-officer-facing-21-charges-of-fraud-involving-at-least-17-million</ref> Yeo was interdicted from his position as head of field research and technical support at CPIB to assist in a Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) probe into his suspected financial impropriety. Eight of the charges were for misappropriating funds and [[Penal Code (Singapore)#Criminal breach of trust|criminal breach of trust]], one was for forgery and the rest were in using part of his ill-gotten gains to gamble at the [[Marina Bay Sands]] (MBS) casino.<ref>https://sg.news.yahoo.com/senior-cpib-officer-charged-with-embezzling-s-1-7-million-015009043.html</ref> On 20 February 2014, Yeo was sentenced to 10 years jail.<ref>http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/former-cpib-assistant-director-jailed-10-years-0</ref>
===MFA (2014)===
On 20 February 2014, former Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) protocol chief Lim Cheng Hoe, 61, was sentenced to 15 months' jail for cheating. From February 2008 to May 2012, Lim made false claims for $89,000 worth of pineapple tarts and wine as gifts for foreign diplomats.<ref>http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/ex-mfa-protocol-chief-lim-cheng-hoe-sentenced-to-15-months-jail-for-cheating</ref><ref>http://www.asiaone.com/singapore/former-mfa-protocol-chief-lim-cheng-hoe-pleads-guilty-10-counts-fraud</ref>
===Ang Mo Kio Town Council (2016)=== General manager and secretary of [[Ang Mo Kio]] Town Council (AMKTC), Victor Wong Chee Meng, was removed from his position and placed under investigation by CPIB, after a complaint was lodged in September 2016 over "the way he handles contracts and dealings in the town council". Wong, a [[Pingat Bakti Masyarakat|Public Service Medal]] recipient, was concurrently an employee of [[CPG Corporation|CPG]] Facilities Management, which is the appointed managing agent of the town council.<ref>https://sg.news.yahoo.com/ang-mo-kio-town-council-general-manager-investigated-by-cpib-234748175.html</ref><ref>https://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2016/12/30/general-manager-of-pap-town-council-removed-from-duties-and-placed-under-cpib-investigations/</ref> On 14 March 2018, Wong is charged with 55 counts of corruption offence for receiving some $107,000 in bribes from Chia Sin Lan and Yip Fong Yin, directors of two building and repair companies.<ref>https://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2018/03/14/former-general-manager-of-ang-mo-kio-town-council-charged-in-court-for-alleged-corruption/</ref>
===Keppel Corporation (2017)===
According to US prosecutors, [[Keppel Corporation|Keppel]]’s offshore and marine arm, Keppel O&M, agreed to pay a US$422 million settlement to avoid a criminal trial for bribing Brazilian officials. Court documents released by the US justice department revealed that Keppel O&M paid US$55 million in bribes between 2001 and 2014, to win 13 contracts with [[Petrobras]] and Sete Brasil – two Brazilian oil companies deeply mired in the country’s wide-ranging [[Operation Car Wash]] graft scandal.<ref>http://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/2126198/oil-bribes-politicians-what-happened-clean-singapore</ref> Keppel Corporation is one of the [[State-owned enterprise|Government-Linked Companies]] (GLCs) under [[Temasek Holdings]].<ref>https://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2017/12/29/workers-party-to-file-parliamentary-questions-on-keppel-corruption-scandal/</ref> It is currently the biggest corruption case involving a GLC in Singapore’s history.
===Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) (2018)=== Rajkumar Padmanathan, 49, was jailed 25 months and six weeks on 27 July 2018 for 28 counts of corruption, cheating and breaching the Official Secrets Act while working at Tengah Air Base and Sembawang Air Base. He leaked tender quotations in order to secure contracts for companies set up by his wife, Jayashree, friend, Jeevan Arumugam, and acquaintance, Kamal Kishore. The total value of contracts awarded to GAS, EFAS, Duratech and GTW set up for the scam was $1,817,379.87 over the period from 2008 to 2014.<ref>https://sg.news.yahoo.com/ex-rsaf-engineer-cheated-government-1-8m-contracts-jailed-102407295.html</ref>
== See also == * [[Crime in Singapore]] * [[Trans-Pacific Partnership]] * [[City Harvest Church Corruption Case]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Corruption in Singapore|Corruption in Singapore]] [[Category:Corruption by country|Singapore]]

{{refimprove|date=October 2018}}{{Essay-like|date=February 2018}} [[File:White-tailed_deer.jpg|thumb|350px|Due to the deer's prevalence across different types of terrain, importance as a game animal and free and unrestricted nature the animal is a popular component of country symbolism.]]
'''Country''', as an [[Self-concept| identity]] or descriptive quality, is the state or character of being rural regardless of environment. It can be at direct odds with quantitative measures of ruralness such as [[Rural area| those used by governments for statistical analysis]]. Country is [[Subjectivity| subjective]] and often [[intuitive]]. It encompasses a broad base of ideas and perceptions that may differ at local, regional or national levels. The term country can be used to refer to individuals both in singular and plural, while the term '''countryfolk''' is exclusively used collectively.
==Social development== Identity has the tendency to be more localized within relatively isolated populations. Such populations, having distinct traditions of their own, can often be viewed as an [[Ingroups_and_outgroups| outgroup]] and marginalized by the dominant culture. Accordingly, contrast between rural and urban realities not only produces measurable differences politically and economically, but also affects populations in terms of social identification.<ref name="knowingyourplace">{{Citation | last = Ching, Barbara, and Gerald W. Creed. | first = | year = 1997 | title = Knowing Your Place: Rural Identity and Cultural Hierarchy | publisher = Routledge | place = New York }}</ref> Country conceptualization shifts the focus away from the prevailing forces in society (usually centered in larger, metropolitan regions) and towards those on the periphery of society (remote areas and small towns). Consequently, this transition causes rural populations to feel less ignored, better connected with rural [[diaspora]] and significantly more empowered. By extension this transition highlights that rural culture is pervasive and does not necessarily depend on residing in a rural area. As a result country conceptualization often assists in reversing the psychological consequences of frequent marginalization. [[File:Town_mouse_country_mouse.png|left|{{largethumb}}|An illustration of [[The_Town_Mouse_and_the_Country_Mouse| "The Town Mouse and Country Mouse"]] of ''Aesop's Fables'' an early parable of urban and rural equality/divide.]] ==Cognitive definitions== Country is a [[Subjectively| subjective state]] that perceives the [[rural area| rural]] [[experience]] as focal and inseparable to ones [[collective identity| identity]], regardless of location. This is often expressed in the [[social exclusion| demarginalization]] of ideas, values or lifestyles held as being representative of such a character. A concise understanding of Country as an overarching concept is difficult due to the tendency by observers to equate it with frequently associated elements. As well, by individuals and groups denoting Country with classification that limits in such terms (IE "rural working-class culture" or "southern culture"). However it is perhaps best epitomized not in objective elements, as place, class or [[Natural environment|environment]], but rather in its subjective symbolism and by the perception that individuals can continue to retain a sense of ''ruralness'' even in urbanized areas. As there is no definitive, scholarly consensus on precisely what constitutes as Country, much of its discourse can be attributed to the artistic community who describe it in [[Romanticism| romanticized]] ways. In her master thesis, ''Manifestations of Collective Identity in Country Music - Cultural, Regional, National'', Stephanie Schäfer denotes that [[country music]] is important tool for reinforcing this collective identity. <ref name="schafer">{{ cite thesis | last=Schäfer | first=Stephanie | authorlink= | ISBN=978-3-8428-2301-3 | publisher=Diplomica Verlag GmbH | title=Manifestations of Collective Identity in Country Music - Cultural, Regional, National | url= | year=2011 | degree=MA }}</ref> Despite Schäfer's analysis of country music as losing much of its "ground" in recent years through commercialization, even modern songs such as ''[[How Country Feels]]'' (Randy Houser), ''[[A Little More Country Than That]]'' (Easton Corbin), ''I'm Country'' (Craig Morgan), ''[[She's Country]]'' (Jason Aldean), etc. continue to, directly or indirectly, address the topic of Country conceptualization. For example, Luke Bryan in ''[[Doin'_My_Thing| What Country Is]]'' illustrates Country by contrasting it with what it is not. He elaborates that:
{{quotation|"It [Country] ain't a jacked up truck that's never seen a pasture,
It's cars pulling over for a no cap tractor,
It's homemade peach ice cream on sun-burnt lips,
No, it can't be bought it's somethin' you're born with,
That's what country is."}}
This emphasis of non-material culture over material resonates with the rural experience as being represented through material elements rather than solely consisting of them. Within the United States country frequently transcends a close relationship with the [[Culture of the Southern United States]] as a source of unity and empowerment of local, marginalized peoples who feel left out from the dominant culture. The preference to identify as country before more tradition means of classification, such as race or class, is reflected of [[self-determination theory]]. As human beings have an inherent drive to better their association with others they consistently try to do so more effectively. Country identification is one way in that an individual strives for this realization by identifying in ways that are more advantageous to rural populations and not necessarily in ways dictated by mainstream society.

'''David Lionel Mayhew''' [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] (born May 1940) is a British banker, chairman of [[JP Morgan Cazenove]] until 2011.
==Early life== David Lionel Mayhew was born in May 1940.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/UgAnKPSUhxjLQaa_rLYQNSgjW3M/appointments|title=David Lionel MAYHEW - Personal Appointments (free information from Companies House)|author=|date=|website=beta.companieshouse.gov.uk|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref> He was educated at [[Eton College|Eton]], and left with 4 [[O level]]s.<ref name="standard.co.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/mayhew-the-legend-6953646.html|title=Mayhew the legend|author=|date=|website=standard.co.uk|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref>
==Career== Mayhew joined the merchant bank [[Cazenove (stock broker)|Cazenove]] as a partner in 1968, and worked there for more than 40 years.<ref>http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/99/Cazenove-Group-plc.html</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/8932817/David-Mayhew-last-of-the-City-old-school.html|title=David Mayhew: last of the City old school|first=Jeremy|last=Warner|date=4 December 2011|publisher=|accessdate=28 January 2018|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> On standing down as chairman of [[JP Morgan Cazenove]] in November 2011, the ''[[New York Times]]'' called him "one of Britain’s most respected bankers".<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2011/11/29/david-mayhew-steps-down-as-jpmorgan-cazenove-chairman/|title=Mayhew Steps Down as Chairman of J.P. Morgan Cazenove|first=Mark|last=Scott|date=|website=nytimes.com|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref> Mayhew subsequently became a vice chairman of global investment banking for [[JPMorgan Chase]].<ref name="auto"/> He was appointed CBE in the [[2011 Birthday Honours]].
==Personal life== Mayhew is married to Ginny, a former model, they have three children, and live in Hampshire.<ref name="standard.co.uk"/> He collects art, and is a member of Boodle's and the City of London club.<ref name="standard.co.uk"/> In May 2017, he gave £25,000 to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cityam.com/264987/party-donors-biggest-names-bank-rolling-conservative|title=Party donors: Here are the big names bank-rolling the Conservative campaign|first=Helen|last=Cahill|date=18 May 2017|website=cityam.com|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref>

{{Infobox organization | logo = European_Institute_of_Cultural_Routes_-_logo.png | map = [[Luxembourg (ville)|Luxembourg]] {{LUX}} | headquarters = [[Abbaye de Neumünster]] | leader_title = President | leader_name = Colette Flesch | leader_title2 = Director | leader_name2 = Stefano Dominioni | name = European Institute of Cultural Routes | website = http://www.culture-routes.net }}
The '''European Institute of Cultural Routes''' is a non-profit association based in [[Luxembourg]] whose aim is to help the [[Council of Europe]], as a technical body, in the establishment of [[European Cultural Route]]s.
It was established in 1998 and its role is:<ref>[http://www.coe.int/t/e/cultural_co%2Doperation/heritage/european_cultural_routes/_Summary.asp Council of Europe Cultural Routes]</ref> * to examine applications for new projects; * to monitor activities in the field and co-ordinate the work of partner organizations; * to disseminate and archive information documents.
The Council of Europe: :'' entrusted the Institute to follow up the already elected routes, to co-ordinate and provide technical aid to networks, in particular in their development in Central and Eastern Europe, to initiate new proposals as well as to disseminate information and set up a database that will constitute the memory of the programme of the cultural routes.''<ref>[http://www.culture-routes.lu/php/fo_index.php?lng=en&dest=bd_pa_det&unv=qs&PHPSESSID=b24ba209aa34a60d8b5926f310540d44 European Institute of Cultural Route - Who are we?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614223213/http://www.culture-routes.lu/php/fo_index.php?lng=en&dest=bd_pa_det&unv=qs&PHPSESSID=79953ec9b359b9db14bf01bb6d416bcd |date=2006-06-14 }}</ref>
'''The European Institute of Cultural Routes'''
The European Institute of Cultural Routes (EICR) was established as a European public service and technical body as part of a political agreement between the Council of Europe and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg (Ministry of Culture, Further Education and Research). Since 1988 the Institute has worked in close collaboration with the Council of Europe in carrying out its responsibilities, namely to ensure the continuity and development of the programme of the Cultural Routes in the 51 signatory countries of the [[European Cultural Convention]] and, depending on the geographical and historical requirements of the themes, in those countries which have had and continue to have close relations with Europe.
The EICR resides in the [[Neumünster Abbey|Centre Culturel de Rencontre – Abbaye de Neumünster]], in Luxembourg. It retains all relevant documentation and maintains a specialist library on the routes. The Institute regularly welcomes those in charge of the networks of the routes as well as project managers, researchers, students and members of the general public. The EICR is also charged with participating in European training, research and analysis programmes concerning cultural tourism, for the European Commission and various governments and project managers. The Institute organises themed symposiums and specialist training, collaborates in the setting up and running of the Routes, and participates in specialist exhibitions while promoting a greater awareness of the links between culture, tourism and the environment.
From 2004 to 2006 the Institute managed the visibility and communication work of the European research programme PICTURE (Proactive management of the impact of cultural tourism on urban resources and economies).
In 2008 the [[European Commission]] (Directorate-General Education and Culture) named the EICR as a body active on a European level in the field of Culture, in recognition for its essential role in creating a coherent programme of sustainable cultural tourism initiatives promoting the “Destination Europe” and encouraging Europeans to discover their common roots and history through travel and the exploration of material and immaterial heritage.
The Institute is a member of NECSTOUR, an association of European regions working to develop competitive and sustainable tourism, and has signed an agreement with the Cité de la Culture et du Tourisme durable to provide distance-learning and to study the sustainability of introducing tourism to the cultural routes. The Institute is currently working with the Council of Europe and the Tourism Unit of the European Commission on a study into the impact of the cultural routes on small and medium businesses.
In 2011 the Institute welcome a Partial Agreement aimed at combining the voluntary contributions of those member countries of the Council of Europe who wish to increase the funds available to the cultural routes.
Since the opening up of Europe to the East, the Cultural Routes have enabled, and continue to enable (particularly by expanding to include the Southern Caucasus), the creation of a real dialogue between Eastern and Western Europeans. The opening of a resource centre for the Cultural Routes in Sibiu, in the Casa Luxembourg, in liaison with the European Institute of Cultural Routes in Luxembourg and the Mioritics Association is testament to this.
Stefano DOMINIONI is the current Director of the Institute and Executive Secretary of the Enlarged Partial Agreement on Cultural Routes of the Council of Europe. Michel Tomas Penette and Penelope Denu directed the Institute from 1998 to 2011 and from 2011 to 2015 respectively.
[[Colette Flesch|Colette FLESCH]] is President of the Institute since 2013. She replaced [[Erna Hennicot-Schoepges]] and Guy Dockendorf.

A '''Faith-based organization''' is an organization whose values are based on faith and/or beliefs, which has a mission based on social values of the particular faith, and which most often draws its activists (leaders, staff, volunteers) from a particular faith group. The faith to which the organization is relating to does not have to be academically classified as [[religion]]. The term "faith-based organization" is more inclusive than the term "[[religious organization]]" as it refers also to the non-congregation faith beliefs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bielefeld|first=Wolfgang|last2=Cleveland|first2=William Suhs|date=2013-06-01|title=Defining Faith-Based Organizations and Understanding Them Through Research|url=http://nvs.sagepub.com/content/42/3/442|journal=Nonprofit and Voluntary Sector Quarterly|language=en|volume=42|issue=3|pages=442–467|doi=10.1177/0899764013484090|issn=0899-7640}}</ref>
Faith-based organizations are [[Grassroots|grass-root]] organizations active locally but also on an international<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icrc.org/eng/assets/files/other/irrc_858_ferris.pdf|title=Faith-based and secular humanitarian organizations|last=Ferris|first=Elisabeth|date=June 2005|editor-link=[[International Revue of the Red Cross]]|website=International Revue of the [[Red Cross]]|publisher=[[ICRC]]|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref> scale. Their funding comes from member donations, but they are also eligible for state<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usaid.gov/work-usaid/partnership-opportunities/faith-based-community-organizations/faith-based-organizations|title=Faith-Based Organizations FAQ|website=www.usaid.gov|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref> or international grants.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nonprofit.about.com/od/faqsthebasics/f/What-Is-A-Faith-Based-Nonprofit.htm|title=How Is a Faith-Based Nonprofit Different From Other NPOs?|website=About.com Money|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref>
Currently, this terminology is widely used in governmental,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usaid.gov/partnership-opportunities/fbci|title=Faith-Based & Community Organizations|website=www.usaid.gov|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/administration/eop/ofbnp|title=The President and Vice President Speak at the Easter Prayer Breakfast|website=The White House|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref> inter-governmental,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/education/themes/leading-the-international-agenda/education-for-sustainable-development/partners/faith-based-organizations/|title=Faith-based organizations {{!}} Education {{!}} United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|website=www.unesco.org|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/EXTABOUTUS/PARTNERS/EXTDEVDIALOGUE/0,,contentMDK:21955855~menuPK:5554941~pagePK:64192523~piPK:64192458~theSitePK:537298,00.html|title=Development Dialogue on Values and Ethics – Partnerships with Faith-Based Organizations|website=web.worldbank.org|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref> and non-governmental settings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usaid.gov/work-usaid/partnership-opportunities/faith-based-community-organizations/faith-based-organizations|title=Faith-Based Organizations FAQ|website=www.usaid.gov|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref> [[World Bank]] prepared a list of international faith-based organizations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/EXTABOUTUS/PARTNERS/EXTDEVDIALOGUE/0,,contentMDK:22363829~pagePK:64192523~piPK:64192458~theSitePK:537298,00.html|title=Development Dialogue on Values and Ethics – Directory of Faith-based Organizations|website=web.worldbank.org|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref>

'''Fourth Polish Republic''' ({{lang-pl|IV Rzeczpospolita}} or ''IV RP''), a plan for moral revolution and political change put forth in 1997 by the Polish conservative philosopher Rafał Matyja in the magazine "Nowe Państwo" ("New Country"). "Fourth Republic" was a political [[slogan]] used by the right-leaning [[Law and Justice|Prawo i Sprawiedliwość]] (PiS) party in the [[Polish parliamentary election, 2005|2005 Polish parliamentary election]].
According to PiS, the current [[Third Polish Republic]] is a post-communist creation whose very foundations must be changed to create a truly democratic state free of its past.
“IV RP”, along with it's derivate, “V RP” (''Fifth Polish Republic''), has also been used by the critics to satirize the concept of unnecessary constitutional changes made for arbitrary reasons.
